contents.value: Template

description.value: The world doesn't see you the way you see yourself.

contents.value: The world doesn't see you the way you see yourself. You might be inclined to underestimate yourself because you focus too much on your shortcomings. A better approach to anything you wish for is to go there and just try, even if you have self doubt. You want to apply for a new job? You wish to ask for a pay raise or a promotion? All you need to do be frank about your expectations. Remember that they do not have the doubts about you that you have within yourself, they are not you (duh!). And, what worse can happen? You don't get what you wished for? Well, with all those self doubts and without trying, it was all the same anyway. So why not try and find out?

description.value: Bad stays bad, worse gets to be good.

contents.value: I think I saw some YouTube reel about this theory, which actually makes sense. It says that often times we settle for things that we don't really enjoy or that don't make us happy because in our minds we keep thinking it's not worse yet. We go for bad because things aren't worse yet, had they been worse we would do something about it but they are not so we don't. Do you see the irony here?

For example consider a job that makes you unhappy but not outright miserable, you stick to it because it is not bad enough. But what if it was bad enough, then you will do something about it. Worse forces you to strive for good but bad doesn't. Funny right?
This applies to various situations in life not just a job. It can be about a place, a relationship, a friendship, a situation or something else.
I have been meaning to write about this for a while, but this is something quite personal to me and I didn't really want it to be judged from the likes, upvotes, claps etc of the internet.
And so I have been making this website for past few months, primarily to share my most intimate thoughts unhindered and uninhibited. (and hopefully more coherent with the passage of time)

I have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) or Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD). This is not something that I have somehow acquired as I grew older but it is something I am born with. It is the way my brain is wired. Different than most, not in a romantic sense but quite literally.
ADD/ADHD?
Dopamine, Norepinephrine or Noradrenaline are neurotransmitters in our brains which are responsible for attention.
Dopamine - is involved in movement, memory, reward and motivation, behavior and cognition, attention, sleep and arousal, mood, learning and in case of women lactation.
Norepinephrine - increases alertness, arousal, attention, affects sleep-wake cycle, mood and memory, helps maintain blood pressure at time of stress.

Most people have sufficient levels of these but for people like me, we don't. Our natural levels of these neurotransmitters is low. So our ability to pay or sustain attention is heavily impaired among other effects. Hence the name Attention Deficit. Hyperactivity is another facet of this impaired attention.
How does affect me?

Think of computer with faulty RAM. This computer will have trouble in reading and writing data and it will also have a hard time processing the data. This is exactly what happens in ADHD brain, faulty RAM is quite similar to poor attention (poor working memory) and data can be analogous to long term memory. Computer data must go through RAM for any operation, faulty RAM affects every aspect of a computer. And quite similarly ADHD affects all aspects of life.

ADHD people face difficulties even in simplest of tasks, because of their poor working memory. They have a hard time performing academically, coping emotionally among countless other difficulties. I can attest to that from my own personal experience.

description.value: A few songs I have discovered recently.

contents.value: A few months back while scrolling on YouTube Shorts, I came across a video that played a lofi, fast forwarded cover of some song that I had never heard. The words and the melody were too good to forget, so I ended up shazaming it and thanks to Spotify and it's suggestions found a playlist worth of (mainly old) rock songs.
https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/6DFfL4N9SFFkYX5YjfOzEU?utm_source=generator
And also, that song was Somewhere Only We Know by Keane.
https://www.youtube.com/embed/jrGBl9ssHXk

From the age of 19 to 24, I was stuck in a vicious loop. What ever I tried to learn, a new subject, a new hobby or anything else I would always get too overwhelmed because of it's complexity or too bored because of it's simplicity, but that wasn't even the worst of it. The most frustrating part was that every time I made some progress while trying to learn something, I will forget it the next time, so I will have to start over and over again until I give it up or settle for something mediocre. Kind of like going up on an escalator which is going down, chances are you'll end up going nowhere or get injured badly. It made my life hell, academically or otherwise.

It gave me anxiety, countless breakdowns but no explanations. I tried different things hoping to sort it out, meditations, exercise etc. They helped in making me feel better (Dopamine boost) when I was otherwise not but never really helped fixing the problem.

So after 5 years of accumulated frustration, in which I somehow dragged myself through college, got a job, got so frustrated with my head that almost quit the job, consulted a psychiatrist for almost a year - I finally got an answer, hope and treatment and it saved my life, really it did. It was undiagnosed and untreated Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), in my case predominantly inattentive.
My brain lacked the normal levels of Dopamine & Norepinephrine (as I understand it, brain chemicals responsible for regulation of attention/working memory).

I often wondered why it didn't come up during school? In retrospect it appears the signs were always there, but while living with parents, they created enough structure around me that held everything together, but once I was out of home, all hell broke loose.
https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2017/05/26/07/37/animal-2345418_1280.jpg
Note to self.

Consider slowing down a little bit. Not everything has to happen as quickly as possible. You can put that sock on a bit slowly you know? You can take 5 more minutes to eat that breakfast. You don't have to reach the office within 5 minutes, you can take 15.

I know often time there's this lingering unease within yourself, this restless feeling as if everything you do is dictated by a deadline. But it's not. You don't need to gulp down a glass of water as if it's going to evaporate if you don't, you can take your time.

Try this, every time you become aware that you are rushing through something, stop, take a deep breath, close your eyes  (not while driving) and imagine yourself to be a video that's going too fast. You need to push that 0.75x button.
And once that button is pushed, try enjoying whatever it is that you are doing, notice your breathing, is it too shallow? Try breathing a bit deeper.
Almost everything will be exactly the same even if you took a little bit more time, but you will be different. You will be calmer and less anxious.
Note to self.
Effort is like drying cloths.
Its results are subtle and can take time to be truly visible. No matter how hard a soaked cloth is rinsed, it will never be dry enough right away. But given enough time, it will be bone dry.
Be patient.
https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/1v8xEcEXbUem8acTaL7pMG?utm_source=generator
